reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s scale/population-ethics line of thought, which is one contributor to the “eutopia is fragile / target is narrow” conclusion but not the core or sole support (the argument also rests on many other ‘single-flaw’ dimensions, the multiplicative model, bounded/unbounded value-function analysis, digital minds, bads vs goods aggregation, etc.). So centrality is modest. Strength is low because the critique is largely generic and mischaracterises the paper as ‘assuming’ scale is always morally relevant in the same way; the essay explicitly canvasses divergent population ethics (total, critical-level, variable-value) and uses them to argue that many plausible views create fragility, not that “more is always better.” The point that the essay does not deeply engage the Repugnant Conclusion (or other familiar population-ethics objections) is somewhat fair, but it’s underdeveloped and doesn’t show that the paper’s claims about fragility/fussiness fail. Clarity is good despite being brief. Dead weight is low because nearly all content is doing argumentative work. It focuses on essentially one issue.
title: Scale-sensitive ethics must address the Repugnant Conclusion and quality-based objections
